skills.name: Complete mental subtraction problems up to 10

explanations.A: I think you may have miscounted. Consider drawing a number line to help you.
explanations.B: If we start on 8 and count down by 6... 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2... the answer would be 2. We could also do 6 + 2 = 8, to check our answer.
explanations.C: I think you may have counted the starting number. Consider drawing a number line to help you.
explanations.D: You have added the two numbers. The question asks you to subtract.

explanations.A: I think you may have miscounted. Consider drawing a number line to help you.
explanations.B: I think you may have counted the starting number. Consider drawing a number line to help you.
explanations.C: You have added the two numbers. The question asks you to subtract.
explanations.D: If we start on 9 and count down 2... 8, 7... so the answer must be 7. We can check our answer by doing 2 + 7 = 9.

explanations.A: Almost! But I think you counted 18, 17, 16. Remember when we subtract we don't count the starting number, so count 17, 16, ...
explanations.B: The starting point 18 is 10 bigger than 8, so the answer will be 10 bigger than 5. 5 + 10 = 15.
explanations.C: Not quite, 6 is only 1 bigger than 5, but 18 is 10 bigger than 8.
explanations.D: Not quite, 8 changed to 18 on the second line, can you make the same change to the answer? What's the value of that 1 in 18?

explanations.A: The starting point ,19, is 10 bigger than 9, so the answer will be 10 bigger than 6. 6 + 10 = 16.
explanations.B: Almost! But I think you counted 19, 18, 17. Remember when we subtract we don't count the starting number, so count 18, 17, ...
explanations.C: Not quite, 7 is only 1 bigger than 6, but 19 is 10 bigger than 9.
explanations.D: Not quite, 9 changed to 19 on the second line, can you make the same change to the answer? What's the value of that 1 in 19?

explanations.A: From 13 to 10 she subtracted 3. Then if she wants to subtract 7 altogether, the next jump must be -4 (3 + 4 = 7)
explanations.B: That's the position on the number line after subtracting 7 from 13, but we want to know what has been subtracted when the calculation is split up like this.
explanations.C: I think you decided Amy needed to subtract 5 more, but she has subtracted 3 already. 3 + 5 makes 8, not 7.
explanations.D: Not quite - Amy has subtracted 3, how many more does she need to jump back to subtract 7 in total?

explanations.A: Not quite - Amy has subtracted 6, how many more does she need to jump back to subtract 9 in total?
explanations.B: That's the position on the number line after subtracting 9 from 16, but we want to know what has been subtracted when the calculation is split up like this.
explanations.C: I think you decided that Amy needed to subtract 4 more, but she has subtracted 6 already. 6 + 4 makes 10, not 9.
explanations.D: From 16 to 10 she subtracted 6. Then if she wants to subtract 9 altogether, the next jump must be -3 (3 + 6 = 9).

explanations.A: This number line uses adding to show the difference between 8 and 13, so it's the same as a subtraction! Which diagram doesn't have the same result as subtracting 8?
explanations.B: This number line shows subtracting 3 and subtracting 5. Altogether, that's the same as subtracting 8. Which diagram doesn't have the same result as subtracting 8?
explanations.C: This number line shows subtracting 10 then adding 2. This is the same as subtracting 2 less than 10, so subtracting 8. Which diagram doesn't have the same result as subtracting 8?
explanations.D: This diagram shows subtracting 1 seven times, which is the same as subtracting 7. Therefore, this does not show 13 - 8.

explanations.A: This diagram shows subtracting 10 then adding 6, which is the same as subtracting 4 from 13. Therefore, this does not show 13 - 6.
explanations.B: This number line shows subtracting 3 and then subtracting another 3. Altogether, that's the same as subtracting 6. Which diagram doesn't have the same result as subtracting 6?
explanations.C: This number line shows subtracting 10 then adding 4. This is the same as subtracting 4 less than 10, so subtracting 6. Which diagram doesn't have the same result as subtracting 6?
explanations.D: This diagram shows subtracting 1 six times, which is the same as subtracting 6. Which diagram doesn't have the same result as subtracting 6?

explanations.A: The total of 6 and 5 is 11, so subtracting 6 and subtracting 5 is the same as subtracting 11. Try doing each calculation to check which one is not the same as 16 - 11.
explanations.B: The total of 10 and 1 is 11, so subtracting 10 and subtracting 1 is the same as subtracting 11. Try doing each calculation to check which one is not the same as 16 - 11.
explanations.C: If we subtract 10 then add 1, overall we are subtracting one less than 10. This is the same as subtracting 9, not subtracting 11.
explanations.D: Both numbers start with 10, and we know 10 - 10 is 0 so we can cancel the 10s and still get the same answer. Try doing each calculation to check which one is not the same as 16 - 11.

explanations.A: The total of 6 and 5 is 11, so subtracting 6 and subtracting 5 is the same as subtracting 11. Try doing each calculation to check which one is not the same as 17 - 11.
explanations.B: The total of 10 and 1 is 11, so subtracting 10 and subtracting 1 is the same as subtracting 11. Try doing each calculation to check which one is not the same as 17 - 11.
explanations.C: If we subtract 10 then add 1, overall we are subtracting one less than 10. This is the same as subtracting 9, not subtracting 11.
explanations.D: Both numbers start with 10, and we know 10 - 10 is 0 so we can cancel the 10s and still get the same answer. Try doing each calculation to check which one is not the same as 17 - 11.
